references: Constraints and knowledge. The constraints in optimization (P) characterize the process of poisoning FRL, and their interpretations are summarized in Table 1. The constraint (2) describes how a clean agent iğ‘–i initializes its policy for local training at the beginning of each round. The agent updates its model from Î¸(i)pâˆ’1,Lsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘1ğ¿\theta_{(i)}^{p-1,L} to Î¸(i)p,0superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘0\theta_{(i)}^{p,0} using an update algorithm ğ’œuâ€‹pâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)superscriptğ’œğ‘¢ğ‘â‹…â‹…\mathcal{A}^{up}(\cdot,\cdot). This update algorithm takes the agentâ€™s current model Î¸(i)pâˆ’1,Lsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘1ğ¿\theta_{(i)}^{p-1,L} and the global model broadcast by the server Î¸(0)pâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğœƒ0ğ‘1\theta_{(0)}^{p-1} as inputs, and outputs the agentâ€™s new local model Î¸(i)p,0superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘0\theta_{(i)}^{p,0}. Constraint (3) describes the local update of each clean agent at local step qğ‘q in round pğ‘p. The agent uses its current policy, represented by Î¸(i)p,qâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘1\theta_{(i)}^{p,q-1}, to roll out an observation sequence O(i)p,qâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘1O_{(i)}^{p,q-1}. Then, based on this observation, the agent updates its policy from Î¸(i)p,qâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘1\theta_{(i)}^{p,q-1} to Î¸(i)p,qsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘\theta_{(i)}^{p,q} by maximizing an objective function Jâ€‹(â‹…)ğ½â‹…J(\cdot), defined by the agentâ€™s specific RL algorithm. Moreover, constraints (5) and (6) characterize the malicious agentâ€™s local initialization and update, respectively. Their interpretation is similar to the constraints (2) and (3), except that the local update of a malicious agent is based on the manipulated observation O^^ğ‘‚\widehat{O}. Constraint (7) captures the budget constraint for the attacker, where Dâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)ğ·â‹…â‹…D(\cdot,\cdot) represents the distance between the perturbed (poisoned) observations and the clean observations, which is restricted by a cost budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. The attack power Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon represents the degree of poisoning that is allowed, and it is used to define the limit of the change that can be made to the clean data. Finally, the constraint (8) models the aggregation step of the central server by an aggregation algorithm ğ’œaâ€‹gâ€‹gsuperscriptğ’œğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”\mathcal{A}^{agg}. The inputs of ğ’œaâ€‹gâ€‹gsuperscriptğ’œğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”\mathcal{A}^{agg} are the serverâ€™s current model Î¸(0)pâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğœƒ0ğ‘1\theta_{(0)}^{p-1} and the models sent from agents {Î¸(i)pâˆ’1,L}superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘1ğ¿\{\theta_{(i)}^{p-1,L}\}. The output of ğ’œaâ€‹gâ€‹gsuperscriptğ’œğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”\mathcal{A}^{agg} is the serverâ€™s new global model Î¸(0)psuperscriptsubscriptğœƒ0ğ‘\theta_{(0)}^{p}.

references: Table 2 shows the knowledge of the three parties involved in FL, namely, the coordinator, the attacker, and the agents. The table clarifies the knowledge of each party to guarantee the data privacy expected from FL. The coordinator only has knowledge of the submitted models and the global policy, while the agents only have knowledge of their local data, policy, and the broadcast global model. The attacker only has knowledge of its own observations, manipulations, model, and the broadcast global policy. This ensures that the agentsâ€™ private data is kept confidential.
